reasoning: First off, Netflix isn’t a business I really understand inside my circle of competence. I steer clear of complex technology platforms—streaming content, churn models and giant content budgets aren’t my wheelhouse. Second, its moat looks shallow. Yes, operating margins around 29% suggest scale, but switching costs are low, and competitors from Apple to Disney can undercut pricing or invest in content. Third, management has shown great ambition building content libraries, yet they’ve leaned on debt (debt/equity north of 4) and owner earnings are virtually flat. I respect capital allocation, but piling on leverage to chase growth makes me uneasy. Fourth, the fundamentals and consistency are lacking—ROE under 1%, inconsistent earnings growth (down over 80% in ten periods) and little free cash flow. Fifth, at an intrinsic value of roughly $49 and a negative margin of safety, you’re paying a rich price for a business in decline. Sixth, long-term prospects face red flags: content spending arms races, saturation in developed markets and uncertain subscriber economics. Lastly, I’d rather own wonderful businesses like Coca-Cola, Apple or BNSF at even fairer prices than bet on a fair business at a rich price. In short, I’d sit this one out.

fundamental_analysis.details: Weak ROE of 0.9%; High debt to equity ratio of 4.1; Strong operating margins; Current ratio data not available

consistency_analysis.details: Inconsistent earnings growth pattern; Total earnings growth of -80.9% over past 10 periods

moat_analysis.details: Good ROE performance: 7/10 periods >15%; Decent operating margins (avg: 36.6%) suggest some competitive advantage

book_value_analysis.details: Consistent book value per share growth (Buffett's favorite metric); Excellent book value CAGR: 17.9%

management_analysis.details: No significant new stock issuance detected; No or minimal dividends paid

details: Using three-stage DCF: Stage 1 (-3.5%, 5y), Stage 2 (-1.7%, 5y), Terminal (2.5%)
